metadata.title: Sulfonic acid functionalized covalent organic frameworks as efficient catalyst for the one-pot tandem reactions

Sulfonic acid functionalized covalent organic frameworks as efficient catalyst for the one-pot tandem reactions Kai Gong Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition 1 ⁎ Cunhao Li Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft 1 Daquan Zhang Visualization Investigation Huilin Lu Software Validation Yunyun Wang Visualization Investigation Haoran Li Software Validation Huimin Zhang Software Validation School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Jiangnan University, Wuxi 214122, China School of Pharmaceutical Sciences Jiangnan University Wuxi 214122 China School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Jiangnan University, Wuxi 214122, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. A covalent organic framework containing hydroxyl groups (HO-COF) has been predesigned and synthesized by the cyclotrimerization reaction of acetyls, which was used as a pre-established network to introduce propyl sulfonic acid through post-synthetic modification strategy, for the fabrication of SO3H-COF with graphene-like multilayer structure. SO3H-COF was employed as an effective heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of benzimidazoles, the synthesis of benzodiazepines and one-pot reductive amination of carbonyl compounds. The results indicated that the developed protocol has several advantages, such as high activity, broad substrate scope, short reaction time and excellent yields. The distinctive structures of SO3H-COF endowed the fantastic catalytic properties, good stability and circulation performance. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keyword Covalent organic frameworks Acidic catalyst Benzimidazoles Benzodiazepines Reductive amination 1 Introduction Amines are important organic building blocks for natural products, fine chemicals, pharmaceuticals, dyes and synthetic materials [1,2]. Varieties of methodologies have been reported for the synthesis of amines, such as alkylation of amines [3], reductive amination [4], Buchwald-Hartwig amination [5], Mannich reaction [6] and Ugi reaction [7]. Among those methodologies, reductive amination of carbonyl compounds, categorized as one-pot tandem reaction, is powerful and straightforward approach for the synthesis of amines [8]. As a special kind of amines, nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compounds have their own unique superiority in medicinal chemistry, as exemplified by blockbuster drugs such as osimertinib, atorvastatin, esomeprazole and cimetidine [9–11]. Numerous nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compounds can be synthesized through classical one-pot multi-component reactions, such as, Biginelli pyrimidine synthesis [12], Doebner quinoline synthesis [13] and Hantzsch dihydro-pyridine synthesis [14]. The one-pot reaction strategy shows efficiency in the construction of carbon-carbon and carbon-heteroatom bonds in amine derivatives synthesis, while exhibiting the benefits of simple procedures, high atom-economy and high selectivity [15]. Recently, benzimidazoles and benzodiazepines, typical nitrogenous heterocyclic compounds, have gained significant attention due to their biological properties [16,17]. The common feature is that these one-pot reactions are conventionally performed in the presence of acid catalysts, such as inorganic acid [18], organic acid [19], and solid acid [20]. Regretfully, some of these catalysts may suffer from one or more fatal shortcomings such as long reaction time, poor yields, laborious workup, difficult recycling, especially in environmental pollution. To overcome these real problems, many efforts have been made to develop numerous novel catalysts, such as acid ionic liquids [21] or supported ionic liquids [22], functionalized mesoporous silica [23], Brønsted acidic reduced graphene oxide [24], sulfated polyborate [25] and acid metal organic frameworks (UiO-66-NHSO3H) [26]. So far, the search of high performance catalysts is still on the way, and the developing of novel efficient heterogeneous acid catalysts is particularly desired for the one-pot synthesis of amine derivatives. As a class of crystalline porous polymers, covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have attracted widespread attention in the fields of catalysis, energy storage, sensors and drug delivery [27–30]. COFs are composed of ordered organic units liked by covalent bonds. The functions and potential applications are largely determined by the type of organic units and the framework configuration [31,32]. When serving as catalysts, the careful predesign of functional organic units and precise tailoring of the microstructure of COFs are required to achieve the desired catalytic effect for the designated organic reactions. In order to achieve this purposes, the methodologies including the routine bottom-up strategy and the post-synthetic modification strategy have been developed for the designed synthesis of COFs. However, sometimes, the routine bottom-up strategy could not directly incorporate functional units into the frameworks of COFs, because of the limitation of reaction conditions or the building units [33]. In contrast, the post-synthetic modification is a powerful strategy for introducing novel functional sites into a prefabricated COF to achieve diverse COFs through chemical modification or transformation [34]. In view of this, various functionalized COFs have synthesized by post-synthetic modification strategy and successfully exploited as heterogeneous catalysts in various areas [35–37]. As environmentally benign and “designer” porous polymers, there is still challenging to develop a new methodology for the fabrication of novel functionalized COFs and is a huge space for the development of promising potential in organic synthesis reactions. We are much concerned that functionalized COFs with acid catalytic sites can be fabricated and attractive candidates for applications in the one-pot synthesis of amine derivatives. In continuation of our interest in the design and application of acid catalysts [38,39] and COFs [40], we reported a novel synthesis of sulfonic acid functionalized covalent organic framework (SO3H-COF) through a post-synthetic modification strategy, which was used as an effective heterogeneous acid catalyst for the preparation of benzimidazoles and benzodiazepines, and one-pot reductive amination of carbonyl compounds. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and methods All chemicals and reagents are of analytical grade and used as received without further purification. FT-IR spectra were collected by using a Bruker Tensor II spectrometer. Liquid NMR spectra were performed on a BRUKER AVANCE III (400 MHz) spectrometer. Solid-state NMR spectra were acquired in an Agilent 600 M spectrometer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed using a Hitachi SU8010 microscope. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a JEOL JEM 2100 PLUS microscope. The surface areas were evaluated by the Brunauer-Emmett-teller (BET, Micromeritics ASAP 2460). The Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was used to calculate the pore volume and pore sizes. Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) was carried out using a NETZSCH STA 449F3 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C. 2.2 Synthesis of SO3H-COF Synthesis of 4,4′-biacetyl-2-hydroxylphenyl (DAHP): 4-Acetylphenylboronic acid (172 mg), 4-bromo-2-hydroxyacetophenone (215 mg), K2CO3 (415 mg) and Pd(OAc)2 (7 mg) were added to 5 mL ethanol in 25 mL round-bottomed flask. The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C under nitrogen protection for 2 h. After completion of the reaction, the resulting mixture was separated by filtration. The collected filtrate was concentrated to obtain the crude product. The desired product was afforded by flash column chromatography (eluent: petroleum ether/ethyl acetate, 1/1) with the yield of 92%. Synthesis of HO-COF: DAHP (0.254 g) and p-toluenesulfonic acid (1.92 g) were mixed and transferred to a reaction tube. The mixture was heated to 120 °C for 36 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting solid was washed with H2O, ethanol, and H2O in sequence. The black solid was obtained by a vacuum freezing drying method. Yield: 0.19 g. Synthesis of SO3H-COF : HO-COF (100 mg) and 1,3-propane sultone (2 mL) was added to 10 mL toluene in a reaction tube. The mixture were heated to 120 °C for 10 h. After the reaction completion, the resulting mixture was filtered to obtain the crude product. Soxhlet extraction with ethanol for 12 h get the desired product with the yield of 80%. 2.3 Catalytic performance General Procedure for the Synthesis of Benzimidazoles: Aromatic aldehyde (1 mmol), o-phenylenediamine (1 mmol) and SO3H-COF (10.2 mg) were added to 5 mL ethanol (95%) in a reaction tube. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for an appropriate time (monitored by TLC). After completion of the reaction, SO3H-COF was separated by filtration, washed with ethanol, dried and reused in the next reaction. The organic solvent was concentrated to obtain the crude product. The corresponding product was gained through flash column chromatography (eluent: petroleum ether/ethyl acetate, 5/1 to 4/1). General Procedure for the Synthesis of Benzodiazepines: In a 25 mL reaction tube, a mixture of aromatic aldehyde (1 mmol), cyclic 1, 3-dicarbonyl compound (1 mmol), o-phenylenediamine (1 mmol) and SO3H-COF (10.2 mg) was heated at 120 °C under solvent-free conditions for an appropriate time (monitored by TLC). After completion of the reaction, ethyl acetate was added to the reaction tube. SO3H-COF was separated by filtration, washed with ethyl acetate, dried and reused in the next reaction. The combined organic solvent was concentrated under reduced pressure. The resulting crude product was purified using flash column chromatography (eluent: petroleum ether/ethyl acetate, 6/1 to 4/1) to afford the desired product. General Procedure for One-pot reductive amination of carbonyl compounds: Aromatic amine (1 mmol), aromatic aldehyde (1 mmol), SO3H-COF (10.2 mg) and NaBH4 (2 mmol) was added to 5 mL acetonitrile in a reaction tube. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for an appropriate time (monitored by TLC). After completion of the reaction, CH3OH (5 mL) was added. And then, SO3H-COF was separated by filtration, washed, dried and reused in the next reaction. H2O (10 mL) was added to the filtrate, followed by extracted with ethyl acetate. The organic phase was washed with saturated NaHCO3 aqueous solution, brine and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified through flash column chromatography (eluent: petroleum ether/ethyl acetate, 10/1 to 8/1) to afford the desired product. 3 Results and discussion Based on the cyclotrimerization reaction of acetyls [41,42], we designed a novel synthetic approach to achieve a COF with hydroxyl groups using the monomer 4,4′-biacetyl-2-hydroxylphenyl (DAHP), namely HO-COF. And then, SO3H-COF was fabricated by introducing propyl sulfonic acid groups into the pre-established HO-COF through a post-synthetic modification strategy. The synthetic route for SO3H-COF is shown in detail in Scheme 1 . The FT-IR spectra of DAHP, HO-COF and SO3H-COF are exhibited in Fig. 1 . The characteristic peaks at 3336, 1680, 1491, 958 and 801 cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration of O-H, C=O, C=C, C-OH and the C-H out-of-plane bending vibration of benzene in the diacetyl monomers. Compared with the FT-IR spectra of DAHP, the C=O signal is weakened significantly, indicating that the content of acetyl groups was decreased in HO-COF, due to the cyclotrimerization reaction of acetyls occurring. The bands around 2922 and 2847 cm−1 are associated with the stretching vibrations of CH2 groups of the propyl chains. The characteristic peaks at 1202, 1024 and 625 cm−1 are assigned to the S=O and C-S stretching vibration of sulfonate groups in SO3H-COF, confirming that HO-COF is successfully functionalized with the propyl sulfonic acid group. The total acidity of the SO3H-COF was measured by acid-base titration, which was 2.87 mmol/g. Solid-state NMR technique was carried out to characterize the structure of SO3H-COF (Fig. 2 ). The typical peaks, from 178 to 125 ppm, were attributed to aromatic carbons. The characteristic peaks at 71 and 18 ppm can be ascribed to the carbons of propyl sulfonic acid groups. The Solid-state NMR spectrum of SO3H-COF further confirmed the successful polymerization and post-synthetic modification. SEM images and SEM-EDS basic elemental mapping of SO3H-COF are shown in Fig. 3 . SEM images exhibited that the SO3H-COF features the specific multilayer structure with irregular morphology micro-size. The corresponding element mapping displayed the elementary components (C, O, and S) with a uniform distribution. The TEM images further confirmed that SO3H-COF with graphene-like multilayer structure was fabricated by layer-by-layer self-assembly technology through the electrostatic force and π-π stacking between adjacent sheets. Fig. 4 shows the nitrogen adsorption isotherm curve of SO3H-COF measured at 77 K. SO3H-COF exhibited a typical type I isotherm. The BET surface area of SO3H-COF was determined to be 362 m²/g. The pore size distribution analysis of SO3H-COF was mainly at the range of large micropore and very small mesoporous, indicating the existence of hierarchical porous structures. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) technique was performed to study the thermal performance of COFs (Fig. 5 ). For the pristine HO-COF, an initial minor weight loss of 3% reflects the residual solvent desorption blow 140 °C. HO-COF is thermally stable up to 300 °C, suggesting good thermal stability. While the TGA curve of SO3H-COF exhibits a major weight loss of ∼21% between 200–450 °C that is ascribed to the degradation of propyl sulfonic acid groups. But at temperatures above 800 °C, mass losses of about 45% and 42% were observed for HO-COF and SO3H-COF, respectively. These results indicated SO3H-COF have good thermal stability. To characterize the catalytic performance, SO3H-COF was used as a heterogeneous catalyst for the preparation of benzimidazole derivatives by the condensation reaction of aromatic aldehydes with o-phenylenediamines. The model reaction of p-chlorobenzaldehyde with o-phenylenediamine was investigated to optimize the reaction conditions. As expected without any catalysts, no expected product has been found to prove the necessity of SO3H-COF in this reaction. When the reaction was performed in the presence of SO3H-COF (3.4 mg, 1 mol%) at room temperature, the product yield was up to 82% within 120 min. The product yield increased with increasing the amount of catalyst. As shown in Table 1 , the best results were gained in the presence of SO3H-COF (10.2 mg) for this model reaction. The reaction can occur in either a protic solvent or an aprotic solvent. The best results were gained using ethanol (95% aqueous solution of ethanol) as a reaction solvent. A small amount of water facilitates the reaction, which may be able to protonate of SO3H-COF. Therefore, the optimal conditions determined were that the reaction was promoted by SO3H-COF (10.2 mg) in ethanol (95%) at room temperature. To further prove the catalytic properties of SO3H-COF, the reactions of various aromatic aldehydes with various substituted o-phenylenediamines were performed under the optimal conditions (Table 2 ). A wide range of aromatic aldehydes bearing either electron-donation (such as CH3, OCH3, OH, et al.) or electron-withdrawing groups (such as Cl, NO2, CF3, et al.) gave the desired products with excellent yields at 30∼70 min. The aromatic aldehydes carrying an electron-withdrawing group gave a slightly higher yields and less reaction time than that carrying an electron-donation group. When o-phenylenediamine containing a substituent was carried out, the corresponding product was obtained with longer reaction times. In a word, it can be concluded that SO3H-COF exhibits good catalytic performance in the condensation reaction of aromatic aldehydes with o-phenylenediamines for the synthesis of benzimidazoles. 1,5-Benzodiazepines are typical seven-membered N-heterocycles, which were synthesized by the one-pot multi-component reaction of aromatic aldehydes, o-phenylenediamines and 1, 3-dicarbonyl compounds. Similar to the synthesis of benzimidazoles, the reaction of p-chlorobenzaldehyde, o-phenylenediamine and dimedone was carried out under the above optimal conditions. But no desired benzodiazepine was obtained at room temperature. Usually, as has been reported that the reaction could occur under heating conditions. The yield increased with increasing the reaction temperature. Meanwhile, the results indicated that the reaction can carry out at 120 °C using SO3H-COF (10.2 mg) as catalyst under solvent-free condition within 18 min. The remarkable results encouraged us to expand the reaction substrates. As illustrated in Table 3 , different substituted aromatic aldehydes bearing both electron-donation and electron-withdrawing groups yielded the desired benzodiazepines with excellent yields. Comparing to 1, 3-cyclehexanedione, dimedone reacted in longer times and gave lower yields. Substituted o-phenylenediamines have no obvious effect on the product yields and reaction times. In the above reactions, the common characteristic is that an enamine intermediate is firstly produced, followed by reaction with the other molecule, such as aromatic amine, activated aromatic aldehyde, to produce the desired products. Once the reaction generated an enamine intermediate in reducing environment, one-pot tandem reaction can occur to produce an amine. That is called one-pot reductive amination, reacting in the presence of acid catalyst and reductant. In order to further widen the scope of SO3H-COF, the one-pot reductive amination was investigated (Table 4). The results indicated that various substituted aromatic aldehydes bearing either donating (CH3, OH, et al) or withdrawing groups (Cl, NO2, et al) smoothly reacted with anilines to provide excellent yields in short time at room temperature. Neither the electronic nor steric factors of substituted anilines had distinctly effect on the reductive amination. It is remarkable that acetonitrile was a better solvent to promote this transformation. The recyclability is one of important indicator to evaluate a heterogeneous catalyst. The reaction of p-chlorobenzaldehyde and o-phenylenediamine was investigated to explore the recyclability of SO3H-COF under the above optimal conditions. As shown in Fig. 6 , the results confirmed that SO3H-COF could be reused for no less than six times with only a sight decay in the yields. The outcome of the recycling behavior of SO3H-COF clearly demonstrated the stability and sustainable of the present catalyst. To further highlight the advantage of SO3H-COF, we compared the catalytic performance of this catalyst with previous catalysts in the model reaction for the synthesis of 3d (Table 4 and 5 ). It can be found that SO3H-COF has more catalytic performance than that in the reported literatures. 4 Conclusions In summary, we predesigned and synthesized the HO-COF bearing hydroxyl groups by the cyclotrimerization reaction, which was used as a pre-established network to introduce propyl sulfonic acid through post-synthetic modification strategy, for the fabrication of SO3H-COF. SO3H-COF was used as an effective heterogeneous catalyst for the preparation of benzimidazoles and benzodiazepines, and the one-pot reductive amination. The results indicated that the developed protocol exhibits several advantages, such as high activity, broad substrate scope, short reaction time and excellent yields. This presented methodology is a better and more practical alternative for large-scale synthesis. coredata.dc:description: A covalent organic framework containing hydroxyl groups (HO-COF) has been predesigned and synthesized by the cyclotrimerization reaction of acetyls, which was used as a pre-established network to introduce propyl sulfonic acid through post-synthetic modification strategy, for the fabrication of SO3H-COF with graphene-like multilayer structure. SO3H-COF was employed as an effective heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of benzimidazoles, the synthesis of benzodiazepines and one-pot reductive amination of carbonyl compounds. The results indicated that the developed protocol has several advantages, such as high activity, broad substrate scope, short reaction time and excellent yields. The distinctive structures of SO3H-COF endowed the fantastic catalytic properties, good stability and circulation performance.
coredata.dc:title: Sulfonic acid functionalized covalent organic frameworks as efficient catalyst for the one-pot tandem reactions
